body:
> I will investigate this as well, they do all seem to be related.

By now, I assume your mindmap on this must look like that stereotypical crazy conspiracy theorist pinboard with newspaper clippings and red string? :-)

There seems to be two parts to this bug that I have identified. The first seems to be a problem in pandas. To find the relative horizon the cutoff is taken away from the absolute horizon. To achieve this they are first converted through `to_period()`. The type of output from `to_period` is a `Period` for the cutoff timestamp and a `PeriodIndex` for the `DateTimeIndex`. I suspect the differing types cause an issue in pandas. When one of these is taken from the other, the interval is multiplied by the frequency, hence with 2 hours you get [0, 4, 8, ...] etc. With a frequency of 3H this becomes [0, 9, 18, ...]. However, if I manually create both the cutoff and absolute horizon as `PeriodIndex` then the result is [0, 2, 4, ...] which is the expected result for this part. 

The second problem is in the `_coerce_duration_to_int` where it takes the output of the above and just extracts the integers seemingly ignoring the frequency. I haven't investigated this too thoroughly yet. I will work on fixing this.
@eenticott-shell, could you kindly post minimally reproducing code for the issues? The code I've seen for no.1 narrows it down to `pandas`.

@fkiraly This shows the difference in output between the two types. As far as I am aware these should both produce the same result:

```{python}
import pandas as pd
absolute = pd.PeriodIndex(['2021-01-01 00:00', '2021-01-01 03:00', '2021-01-01 06:00',
             '2021-01-01 09:00', '2021-01-01 12:00'], freq = '3H')

relative_as_PI = pd.PeriodIndex(['2021-01-01 00:00'], freq = '3H')

print(absolute - relative_as_PI)

relative_as_P = pd.Period('2021-01-01 00:00', freq = '3H')

print(absolute - relative_as_P)
```

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Fixes #1935. Fixes #1435. Fixes #1876. 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Within the forecasting horizon methods `to_relative` and `to_absolute_int` coerces absolute and cutoff to the same type to avoid an error that can occur in `pandas` where time differences are multiplied by the frequency multiple (i.e. 2H multiplies the difference by 2). This caused numerous index errors.

 #### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
No

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?
Whether forcing the type of the input to change could have unintended consequences.

issue.title: [BUG] _PmdArimaAdapter setting the wrong relative forecasts for frequency 10T

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Currently while using a dataset that has a datetime index with a frequency of 10T (separated by 10 minutes), the ForecastingHorizon is setting the relative values to increments of 100. This leads to `n_periods` being set as 100 times the actual length `X.shape[0]` of the exogenous variable used in `predict`. This causes a `ValueError` to be raised by the Arima package `X array dims (n_rows) != n_periods`.

To reproduce:
1. Download the dataset `energy_data.csv` from [here](https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/00374/).
2. Set the index as `date`.
3. Separate X and y.
4. Set `dates` as the index of `X` convert as a `datetime`.
5. Convert `dates` to PeriodIndex with the appropriate frequency.
6. Initialize `ForecastingHorizon`, followed by fitting and predicting with `AutoArima`.

```
data = pd.read_csv("../energydata_complete.csv")
data = data[:200]
data.set_index("date", drop=True, inplace=True)
X = data.copy()
y = X.pop("Appliances")

dates = pd.to_datetime(X.index)
freq = pd.infer_freq(dates)
dates = dates.to_period(freq=freq)

X.index = dates
y.index = dates

fh_ = ForecastingHorizon(y.index[150:200], is_relative=False)

a_clf = sktime_arima.AutoARIMA(start_p=2, start_q=2, max_p=5, max_q=5)
clf = a_clf.fit(X=X[:150], y=y[:150])
y_pred_sk = clf.predict(fh=fh_, X=X[150:200])
```

The expectation is that `n_periods = int(fh.to_relative(self.cutoff)[-1])` would set `n_periods` to 50 as there are 50 increments of datetime instances separated by 10 minutes being passed to `predict`. However `fh.to_relative(self.cutoff)` ends up producing this:

`Int64Index([ 100,  200,  300,  400,  500,  600,  700,  800,  900, 1000, 1100,
            1200, 1300, 1400, 1500, 1600, 1700, 1800, 1900, 2000, 2100, 2200,
            2300, 2400, 2500, 2600, 2700, 2800, 2900, 3000, 3100, 3200, 3300,
            3400, 3500, 3600, 3700, 3800, 3900, 4000, 4100, 4200, 4300, 4400,
            4500, 4600, 4700, 4800, 4900, 5000],
           dtype='int64')`

This however is the `ForecastingHorizon` that is used to product that relative index with a cutoff of `2016-01-12 17:50`:

`ForecastingHorizon(['2016-01-12 18:00', '2016-01-12 18:10', '2016-01-12 18:20',
             '2016-01-12 18:30', '2016-01-12 18:40', '2016-01-12 18:50',
             '2016-01-12 19:00', '2016-01-12 19:10', '2016-01-12 19:20',
             '2016-01-12 19:30', '2016-01-12 19:40', '2016-01-12 19:50',
             '2016-01-12 20:00', '2016-01-12 20:10', '2016-01-12 20:20',
             '2016-01-12 20:30', '2016-01-12 20:40', '2016-01-12 20:50',
             '2016-01-12 21:00', '2016-01-12 21:10', '2016-01-12 21:20',
             '2016-01-12 21:30', '2016-01-12 21:40', '2016-01-12 21:50',
             '2016-01-12 22:00', '2016-01-12 22:10', '2016-01-12 22:20',
             '2016-01-12 22:30', '2016-01-12 22:40', '2016-01-12 22:50',
             '2016-01-12 23:00', '2016-01-12 23:10', '2016-01-12 23:20',
             '2016-01-12 23:30', '2016-01-12 23:40', '2016-01-12 23:50',
             '2016-01-13 00:00', '2016-01-13 00:10', '2016-01-13 00:20',
             '2016-01-13 00:30', '2016-01-13 00:40', '2016-01-13 00:50',
             '2016-01-13 01:00', '2016-01-13 01:10', '2016-01-13 01:20',
             '2016-01-13 01:30', '2016-01-13 01:40', '2016-01-13 01:50',
             '2016-01-13 02:00', '2016-01-13 02:10'],
            dtype='period[10T]', name='date', freq='10T', is_relative=False)`

Versions
- Python (3.8.0)
- Sktime (0.5.3)
- pmdarima (1.8.0)

System:

Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/805. Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1935. Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1435. Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1876.

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->

Convert `PeriodIndex` `absolute` to `DatetimeIndex`, as well as `cutoff` and `start` `Period` to `Timestamp` before taking the difference between the two.

This circumvents the following bug in pandas:
```
periods = pd.period_range(start="2021-01-01", periods=3, freq="2H")
periods - periods[0]
Out: Index([<0 * Hours>, <4 * Hours>, <8 * Hours>], dtype = 'object')
[v - periods[0] for v in periods]
Out: Index([<0 * Hours>, <2 * Hours>, <4 * Hours>], dtype='object')
```

Bug report scripts were added as explicit test cases and should be replaced later with lightweight unit tests.
